articles.title: Nation still reeling from winter chills with hotter weather on the horizon
articles.author: George Al-Akiki
articles.summary: Some parts of Victoria and South Australia have been hit with frost warnings this week. The cold snap has been driven by a strong high-pressure system in The Bight. Sydney is set to feel the heat later in the week, reaching a top of 30C by Saturday, while Brisbane will soar up to 31C.

articles.title: Coastal community struggles with worsening crisis that could erase their way of life: 'It's washing away'
articles.author: Samantha Hindman
articles.summary: Coastal community struggles with worsening crisis that could erase their way of life. The Passamaquoddy Tribe of Sipayik (Pleasant Point) is watching the ocean creep higher and foodways fade. The tribe's wastewater plant and several pump stations sit within today's 100-year floodplain and relocation could cost in the tens of millions of dollars.

articles.title: Thinning Arctic sea ice could send 'cold wave' to America, warn scientists
articles.author: Somdatta Maity
articles.summary: Researchers claim that Arctic ice levels can impact the world, which can be felt in North America and Europe. The impact is a consequence of ice cover becoming thin and altering how heat is transferred between the ocean and the atmosphere. The change in pattern of the jet stream also encourages the wind to move towards the south. This direction of wind movement can cause temperatures to fall sharply in large areas of the United States and facilitate heavy snowfall in the Great Lakes region.

articles.title: Building toward disaster: Growth collides with rising seas in Charleston, SC
articles.author: Knoxville Daily Sun
articles.summary: If the water continues to rise in Charleston, Luvenia Brown doesn't want to live there anymore. She watches the weather reports more than she used to, because she's lost hope in the future.    "Growth collides with rising seas" in Charleston.

articles.title: Aus blasts ‘reckless' Russian warplane move
articles.summary: Australia has blasted Russia for a 'dangerous' act involving nuclear-capable warplanes. Russia has been accused of using such weapons on Australia's territory. Russia denies the accusation.       .   in response to Australia's statement.

articles.title: 5.5 million birds expected to fly over Oregon on Monday night. Here's how to help them
articles.author: Sean Sterling
articles.summary: 5.5 million birds are expected to fly over Oregon tonight on their annual migration south. The Bird Alliance of Oregon has issued a Lights Out red alert for September 22, 2025. People are urged to turn off or dim non-essential outdoor lighting from 11 pm to 6 am and close shades to reduce skyglow.

articles.title: U.S. rivers are experiencing unprecedented and unexpectedly intense warming
articles.author: Evan Bush
articles.summary: The frequency, intensity and duration of heat waves is increasing in U.S. rivers. Human-caused climate change is the primary driver of the trend, as snowpack dwindles and streams flow more slowly. Dams slow the flow of water downstream. Buildings and pavement absorb heat that warms the air and then the water. Species that rely on cold water, including salmon and trout, will struggle as streams heat up.

articles.title: 'Over 60k Europeans died from heat in summer of 2024'
articles.summary: 60,000 people died from heat in Europe during last year's record-breaking summer. Europe is heating up twice as fast as the global average. Italy was the country with the most heat deaths last summer with an estimated 19,000, followed by Spain and Germany with over 6,000.

articles.title: Climate Week kicks off with grand opening of immersive art installation on Governors Island
articles.author: Annika Pergament
articles.summary: Climate Week is underway with events scheduled across the city. The Human Impacts Institute kicked off the celebration with the grand opening of 'Echoes of Change,' an immersive art and sound installation at the Climate Imaginarium on Governors Island. The opening of the exhibition leads up to the Institute's Creative Climate Forum on Thursday, Sept. 25 at Pier 57. Tara Deporte, founder and executive director of the Institute, talked about the exhibit and the lineup of events on 'The Rush Hour' on Monday.

articles.title: Mountain of woes: 70 Kullu villages face displacement threat
articles.author: Abhinav Vashisht
articles.summary: Nearly 70 villages in Kullu district are at risk of landslides and land subsidence. The Banjar subdivision has been hit the hardest, with 24 villages under severe threat. In Bandal village alone, 37 houses have been declared unsafe, forcing the evacuation of 28 families. A geological survey attributed the growing instability to road construction on steep slopes, deforestation and changing agricultural practices. Agriculture, the backbone of the local economy, has also suffered. A massive landslide destroyed nearly 200 bighas of farmland, including apple orchards, while forest land was badly damaged.

articles.title: Deadline approaches for McDowell Co. residents to apply for stream bank repairs
articles.author: Mary Kate Howland
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Helene caused stream bank damage in McDowell County, North Carolina. The EWP application deadline is Tuesday, Sept. 30. The information will be used to assist in collecting consolidated impact information and will be provided to other State and Federal agencies.

articles.title: One year after Helene, communities change approach to disaster prep
articles.author: Emily Jones
articles.summary: It's been a year since Hurricane Helene hit Valdosta, Georgia. Now the hardest-hit areas are rebuilding and people are changing how they prepare for the next storm. Lowndes County officials are building up a network of local resources and they are shifting their storm prep advice based on the disasters they've experienced.

articles.title: Neglected Cape Coral home draws safety, health complaints from neighbors
articles.author: Bella Line
articles.summary: Neighbors are concerned about the deteriorating condition of a Cape Coral home. The property has been neglected for nearly three years. It has overgrown grass, a broken pool and a broken fence.       Bella Line spoke with a neighbor about the property.

articles.title: Neglected Cape Coral home draws safety, health complaints from neighbors
articles.author: Bella Line
articles.summary: Tony Lombardo and his wife built their dream home in the area, but the property just steps away has become a daily frustration. The home has sat with significant damage for nearly three years. It features overgrown grass, broken pool cage screens and a pool filled with stagnant brown water. A code hearing for the property is scheduled for October 9th.

articles.title: Dangerous climate change threatens Northern Australia's big ‘food bowl' dreams
articles.author: Steve Turton
articles.summary: The first National Climate Risk Assessment was released last week. It warned extreme heat, fires, floods, droughts and coastal inundation will get worse in coming decades in Northern Australia. Big plans are afoot to turn Northern Australia into Asia's 'food bowl', as part of broader development for the region. Lukas Coch challenged the Northern Australia development agenda from a climate change perspective a decade ago.

articles.title: Spring air is humming with insects. But we're blind to what's happening to them
articles.author: Caitlyn Forster
articles.summary: Spring has arrived in Australia. There is a need for a national insect monitoring network. The Christmas Beetle Count takes photos of Christmas beetles every summer. The Southern Bioblitz is a citizen science project where users upload photos of all kinds of nature to the iNaturalist website.

articles.title: Environment Canada officials grilled on Canada's climate targets at committee hearing
articles.author: Nick Murray
articles.summary: Environment and Climate Change Canada officials struggled to explain how recent federal policy shifts have affected national emissions reduction targets. Assistant deputy ministers appeared before the House of Commons standing committee on environment and sustainable development this morning to brief MPs on the issue. The committee's purpose was to explain the impact of the policy shifts.

articles.title: Climate change induced floods in Pakistan
articles.author: News Desk
articles.summary: Ali Hamid Malik is concerned about the rising frequency and intensity of floods in Pakistan due to climate change. The current floods displaced more than 2 million people, destroyed thousands of villages and wiped out vast stretches of farmland. Pakistan needs a multi-layered and forward-looking strategy to deal with climate change-induced disasters.

articles.title: Trump climate cuts expose local shortfalls, putting forecasts and ag at risk
articles.author: Queensland Country Life
articles.summary: US funding cuts to climate agencies could destabilise global weather forecasting, highlighting need for local sovereignity to protect $80B agriculture industry, according to the UNFCCC's report.   .    "Local sovereignity" is important to protect agriculture industry.

articles.title: Trump climate cuts expose local shortfalls, putting forecasts and ag at risk
articles.author: Jason Gregory
articles.summary: Potential funding cuts to US climate agencies could destabilise global weather forecasting, highlighting the need for Australian sovereign infrastructure. President Trump wants to savagely cut funding to US science and climate agencies, including NASA and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. Australia's $80 billion agriculture sector is highly weather-dependent. The Bureau of Meteorology insists its forecasting remains resilient in sourcing data from about 30 satellites operated by partners in six countries.

articles.title: "Scientists Dig Up 18-Million-Year Monster": Ancient Bird Discovery Shocks Paleontologists While Evolution Theory Crumbles
articles.author: Eirwen Williams
articles.summary: Scientists have discovered a 17-18 million-year-old bird fossil in Queensland, Australia. The newly identified species, Menura tyawanoides, is a close relative of the modern lyrebird. The discovery highlights the importance of national parks in preserving natural history.

articles.title: Brace yourself. The Coalition was right about the climate target
articles.author: Crispin Hull
articles.summary: The cost of reducing emissions is much less than not reducing emissions. Australia should be urging the world to act and set an example as to how it can be done, and done profitably, rather than arguing that Australia will make little difference if the world does not act.

articles.title: Puerto Rico's climate revolution: Taking power back from the grid
articles.author: Kiara Alfonseca
articles.summary: Casa Pueblo in Adjuntas, Puerto Rico, is a self-sustaining community that is self-sufficient on its own resources thanks to the help of solar panels. Climate change is increasing the frequency and intensity of major storms. Puerto Rico's vulnerable power grid collapsed during Hurricane María, which killed more than 3,000 people.

articles.title: Europe's heat deaths climb amid hottest summers on record: Spanish study
articles.author: China.dot.org
articles.summary: Europe recorded 181,000 heat-related deaths over the past three summers. Mediterranean and Southeast regions are most affected. Europe is warming faster than any other continent due to climate change at twice the global average, according to a new study.

articles.title: Climate Change Making Gen Z Less Likely to Have Children-New Survey
articles.author: Suzanne Blake
articles.summary: 38 percent of Gen Z say climate change makes them less likely to have children. 93 percent of Americans are not "very prepared" for a natural disaster. 45 percent of U.S. residents feel numb to disasters like wildfires and hurricanes, and two-thirds admitted to being stressed about the environment.

articles.title: NC lawmakers urge Trump's EPA to protect climate policy
articles.author: Bonnie Zhang
articles.summary: In July, the Trump Administration proposed revoking the 2009 endangerment finding that showed greenhouse gases released from cars were polluting the air and harmful to public health. North Carolina House Representatives Alma Adams, Valerie Foushee and Deborah Ross wrote a letter to EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin to uphold current climate policy. They cited the lives lost and billions in damage caused by Hurricane Helene and rising sea levels in Wilmington as evidence of climate change in North Carolina.

articles.title: The great resetting has begun
articles.author: Tom Arcaro
articles.summary: The great resetting of global priorities is unfolding before our eyes in the waves of the Mediterranean and the docks of Italy, in the streets of world capitals and the whispered consensus of millions. We are not on the brink, we are in the midst of it.

articles.title: 1 year after Hurricane Helene struck North Carolina, some students have yet to return to school
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene devastated western North Carolina's Appalachian region a year ago. More than 2,500 students were homeless as a direct result of the storm, according to state data obtained by The Associated Press. Many families in rural, low-income areas don't get the opportunity to recover.

articles.title: ‘Reckless' Countries to Extract More Than Double the Fossil Fuels Consistent With 1.5°C
articles.author: Julia Conley
articles.summary: The Stockholm Environment Institute, Climate Analytics and the International Institute for Sustainable Development released their latest Production Gap Report on Monday. They found a 110% and 69% gap over the 1.5°C and 2°C limits, respectively, between current and planned fossil fuel production. The report focuses on the 20 largest producers of fossil fuels around the world, including the United States, UK, Australia, Russia, and Canada, responsible for 80% of the world's fossil fuel extraction.

articles.title: Building toward disaster: Growth collides with rising seas in Charleston, SC
articles.author: Ames Alexander
articles.summary: Charleston, South Carolina is one of the fastest-growing cities in the country. It's one of most flood-prone because of rising sea levels and climate change. The city and the federal government are planning a $1.3 billion seawall to defend the downtown peninsula, but it will not extend to lower-income neighborhoods like Rosemont.

articles.title: Building toward disaster: Growth collides with rising seas in Charleston, SC
articles.author: Jeff Basinger
articles.summary: Luvia Brown lives in Charleston, South Carolina's Rosemont neighborhood. She's lost lawn mowers, bikes and outdoor furniture to the rising waters that have repeatedly crept into her yard due to the growth of the marsh.   Â

articles.title: Building toward disaster: Growth collides with rising seas in Charleston, SC
articles.author: Jeff Basinger
articles.summary: Growth and rising seas are colliding in Charleston, South Carolina, where growth and rising sea levels are causing problems.      Â   in the area.  in this article. In this article, we focus on the growth and the rising seas.

articles.title: Building toward disaster: Growth collides with rising seas in Charleston, SC
articles.author: Jeff Basinger
articles.summary: Growth collides with rising seas in Charleston, South Carolina.       .   for floodlightnews.org, part of the BLOX Digital Content Exchange, on BLOX.org.  For confidential support call the Samaritans on 08457 90 90 90, visit a local Samaritans branch, or click here.

articles.title: Europe Had Over 62,700 Heat-Related Deaths In 2024: Report
articles.author: NDTV
articles.summary: More than 62,700 people died in Europe from heat-related causes in 2024, according to research published in Nature Medicine. Women and the elderly represent the largest part of the population affected by the heat- related deaths, with the majority of them being elderly and women.

articles.title: A Scientist's Fight Against Disasters in Kashmir
articles.author: Aashiq Hussain Andrabi
articles.summary: Dr. Kainat Aziz is a Postdoctoral Fellow at the Centre for Sustainable Water Research, IIT Guwahati. She uses satellites, sensors, and long days in the field to track the fragile balance of glaciers, rivers, and mountain slopes. Her research powers early warning systems and disaster plans that could mean the difference between an evacuation and a tragedy.

articles.title: Fall officially arrives with the autumnal equinox. What to know.
articles.author: Washington Post
articles.summary: The autumnal equinox is on Monday at 2:19 p.m. Eastern time. Days are getting shorter, the weather is turning cooler and winter is on the horizon. Earth's tilt on its axis makes the planet lean away from the sun. The planet leans about 23.5 degrees.

articles.title: Europe had over 62,700 heat-related deaths in 2024, report finds
articles.author: The Star
articles.summary: More than 62,700 people died in Europe from heat-related causes in 2024, according to research published in Nature Medicine. Women and the elderly represent the largest part of the death toll, followed by the elderly and the young. Read the full report here.

articles.title: Everything you need to know about Earth's numerous ice ages
articles.summary: There is a general warming of the planet. This has already started to have disastrous effects on the planet, from extreme weather events to crop shortages. Ice ages have ravaged the Earth on numerous occasions, completely changing or even eradicating life on its surface and in its oceans.

articles.title: Over 60,000 Europeans died from heat during 2024 summer, reveals study
articles.author: Khaleejtimes
articles.summary: 60,000 people died from heat in Europe during last year's record-breaking summer. Europe experienced an exceptionally deadly summer in 2024 with more than 60,000 heat-related deaths, bringing the total burden over the past three summers to more than 181,000.

articles.title: ‘Delicious' fall forecast for most of Canada: climatologist
articles.author: Elianna Lev
articles.summary: Climatologist for Environment Canada David Phillips gives his outlook for the autumn season as fall officially starts Monday afternoon. He predicts mild temperatures in most parts of the country, but sweater weather is almost certainly around the corner. Some autumn storms are in the forecast, especially along the east coast.

articles.title: Forecasters eye two more tropical waves as Hilton Head avoids Hurricane Gabrielle's impact
articles.author: Lydia Larsen
articles.summary: Hurricane Gabrielle has strengthened into a Category 3 storm on Monday morning. It is not expected to make landfall along the East Coast and Hilton Head will not see any effects. The National Hurricane Center is monitoring two tropical waves that have a 70% chance of developing into a tropical depression later this week.

articles.title: Cutting down the Amazon will bring extreme rain, wind and heat
articles.author: New Scientist
articles.summary: Deforestation in the Amazon dries out the local climate, but the effects may be even more extreme and varied than previously thought, as the study suggests.   Â. Â   in the study, they found that the effects of deforestation on the climate are more varied and extreme.

articles.title: Met Office reveals how Hurricane Gabrielle will impact UK weather
articles.author: The Mirror
articles.summary: Hurricane Gabrielle is causing dangerous swells in Bermuda. The UK is expecting to feel the fallout from the hurricane's impact on the Atlantic Ocean.    - The hurricane is a category three storm with dangerous winds and heavy rains and is currently over the Atlantic.

articles.title: Canada, other fossil fuel-producing nations, derailing world climate targets, report says
articles.author: Jordan Omstead
articles.summary: Fossil fuel-producing countries are derailing the world's chance to hit key climate change targets, a new report suggests. 2030 production levels are more than double what would be compatible with the Paris agreement. Canada is ranked as a top four oil producer with about 6.5% of the global total.

articles.title: Canada, other fossil fuel-producing nations, derailing world climate targets, report says
articles.author: CBC.ca
articles.summary: Production Gap Report suggests countries are planning to produce 120% more fossil fuels in 2030 than is consistent with keeping global warming to 1.5°C. This is 77% more than what's aligned with a 2°C limit.

articles.title: MTN Ghana's Adwoa Wiafe Calls for Stronger Storytelling to Tackle Climate Change
articles.author: Isaac Kofi Dzokpo
articles.summary: Adwoa Wiafe is the Chief Corporate Services and Sustainability Officer at MTN Ghana. She delivered the keynote address at the Africa Climate Communication Summit 2025 (Virtual Edition). She stressed the importance of storytelling and strategic communication to drive Africa's climate resilience and amplify the continent's voice in global climate conversations.

articles.title: Senegal allocates $4.5 mln relief fund for flood victims
articles.author: Ecofin Agency
articles.summary: $4.5 billion will be spent on relief for flood-affected families in Senegal. $1.8 million will go to drainage works, $2.7 million for direct assistance, including food distribution, shelter equipment, and logistical support. In 2024, exceptional flooding of the Senegal River displaced more than 56,000 people in the east of the country.

articles.title: Dragonflies survived asteroids but may get wiped out by climate change
articles.author: Stephen Beech
articles.summary: Dragonflies are facing extinction due to climate change, warns new research, according to the talker.news website. The article is part of the BLOX Digital Content Exchange, which is a content exchange between BLOX and Talker. News from Talker is available on Talker News.

articles.title: Over 60,000 Europeans died from heat during 2024 summer—study - Jamaica Observer
articles.author: Jamaica Observer
articles.summary: 60,000 people died from heat in Europe during last year, according to the UNICEF. More than 60,000 of them died in France alone.    in Paris.  in 2014. in Paris, France. in 2014  in France.

articles.title: Over 60,000 Europeans died from heat during 2024 summer
articles.author: Naharnet
articles.summary: More than 60,000 people died from heat in Europe during last year's record-breaking summer. Europe experienced an exceptionally deadly summer in 2024. The total burden over the past three summers to more than 181,000, according to the benchmark study.

articles.title: Quotes from Harshbarger, Lee, Trump, Blackburn on Helene
articles.author: Ben Smith
articles.summary: President Trump cares about those affected by Hurricane Helene. He will always stand by the American people in the good times and the bad, according to White House spokeswoman Abigail Jackson. She said one of his first priorities as President was taking action to help individuals that had been ignored for far too long.

articles.title: This is the coldest inhabited place on Earth
articles.summary: Oymyakon is the coldest inhabited place in the world with temperatures below -94°F (-70°C). A small town of settlers has managed to survive there for more than a century. Click through the gallery to marvel at this frozen spectacle of nature.

articles.title: Australia to reverse decision on Palestine recognition with gov't change, Ley tells Sa'ar
articles.author: The Jerusalem Post
articles.summary: The Australian official spoke up for the concerns of her country's Jewish community and the rise of antisemitism. She also spoke out about the humanitarian crisis in the Gaza Strip, which is a concern of the Jewish community in her country, too. She spoke up on behalf of their concerns.

articles.title: How Fear-Based Reporting Is Destroying Rational Climate Debate
articles.author: Marco Kopinke
articles.summary: In recent years, fear-based reporting has become a dominant narrative in the climate change conversation. Fear-driven narratives often create an 'us vs. them' mentality and divide people into alarmists and skeptics. Media should balance urgency with accuracy to maintain public engagement.

articles.title: EPA boss rallies global support for Africa's climate challenges at Harvard University
articles.author: Class
articles.summary: Prof. Nana Ama Brown Klutse is the Chief Executive Officer of Ghana's Environmental Protection Authority. She spoke at the Harvard Climate Symposium in Cambridge, Massachusetts. She warned that the continent faces mounting threats from rising sea levels, community vulnerability, and the intensifying impacts of climate change. Massachusetts Governor Maura T. Healey delivered the keynote.

articles.title: Over 60,000 Europeans died from heat during 2024 summer, reveals study
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: More than 60,000 people died from heat in Europe during last year's record-breaking summer, according to a benchmark study. Europe is heating up twice as fast as the global average. Italy was the country with the most heat deaths last summer with an estimated 19,000. Greece had the highest rate with 574 deaths per million people, followed by Bulgaria and Serbia.

articles.title: Signal 3 hoisted at sea ports as low-pressure system forms in Bay
articles.author: Bangla News24.com
articles.summary: A low-pressure system has developed over the northern Bay of Bengal, prompting authorities to hoist local cautionary signal No. 3 at all maritime ports in Bangladesh. Chattogram, Cox's Bazar, Mongla, and Payra seaports have been advised to keep local warning signal no. 3 hoisted. Fishing boats and trawlers operating in northern Bay are advised to remain close to the coast.

articles.title: What climate targets? Top fossil fuel producing nations keep boosting output
articles.author: Ars Technica
articles.summary: The last two years have seen some of the worst wildfire seasons across Canada, Europe and South America and deadly flooding and heat waves throughout the globe. Over the same period, the world's largest fossil fuel producers have expanded their planned output for the future, setting the world on fire.

articles.title: Neo-Nazis, White Supremacists Participate In Anti-Immigrant 'March For Australia' Rallies In Major Australian Cities
articles.summary: On August 31, 2025, "March for Australia" rallies were held in major cities across Australia. The demonstrations were aimed at protesting against mass immigration into Australia. Several neo-Nazi organizations joined the rallies and introduced their ideology to a broader audience. This report will provide background on the March for Australia rallies and highlight the presence of key neo-Nazis and white supremacists.

articles.title: EPA CEO Prof. Nana Ama Brown Klutse rallies global support for Africa's climate challenges at Harvard University
articles.author: Prosper Kay
articles.summary: Prof. Nana Ama Brown Klutse is the Chief Executive Officer of Ghana's Environmental Protection Authority (EPA). She spoke at the Harvard Climate Symposium in Cambridge, Massachusetts. The symposium was the centerpiece of Harvard Climate Action Week, hosted by the Salata Institute for Climate and Sustainability. Massachusetts Governor Maura T. Healey delivered the keynote, urging massive investment in climate workforce development.

articles.title: Glacier Monitoring Reveals Sharp Ice Loss at Langjökull
articles.author: Michael Chapman
articles.summary: Western Hagafellsjökull glacier has retreated by nearly 1.2 kilometres since 2009. This year's shrinkage was probably greater than last year's, because the summer was warm and the previous one was cold. Scientists warn that Iceland's glaciers are among the most visible indicators of climate change and are expected to vanish within the next century.

articles.title: Hidalgo County seeks input for new hazard mitigation plan
articles.summary: Hidalgo County is updating its Hazard Mitigation Action Plan to address natural hazards and reduce risks to human life and property. The county will host a public meeting on Monday, Sept. 22, at 5 p.m. at the Pharr One Center to discuss updates to the plan and gather community feedback.

articles.title: Over 60,000 Europeans died from heat during 2024 summer: study
articles.author: Julien Dury
articles.summary: More than 60,000 people died from heat in Europe during last year's record-breaking summer. Europe is heating up twice as fast as the global average. An emergency alert system could help warn vulnerable people ahead of dangerous heatwaves, the researchers suggest.

articles.title: Over 60,000 Europeans died from heat during 2024 summer
articles.author: Naharnet Newsdesk
articles.summary: 60,000 people died from heat in Europe during last year's record-breaking summer. Europe experienced an exceptionally deadly summer in 2024 with more than 60,000 heat-related deaths, bringing the total burden over the past three summers to more than 181,000.

articles.title: Europe's Deadly Summer: Heatwaves Claim Over 62,700 Lives
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: 62,700 people died of heat-related causes in Europe in 2024, according to a study published in Nature Medicine. Women and the elderly comprise the majority of the fatalities. Southern Europe bore the brunt, with Italy reporting the highest death toll. Experts call for intensive investment in cooling infrastructure.

articles.title: Climate scientists reveal exactly how many people in Europe DIED from heat-related causes in the summer of 2024 – including more than 500 in the UK
articles.author: JONATHAN CHADWICK
articles.summary: Summer of 2024 was Earth's warmest on record. In Europe, there were 62,775 heat-related deaths between June 1 and September 30. In summer 2024, Italy suffered the most deaths due to the heat, thanks to factors such as Mediterranean climate and ageing population. Spain, Germany, Greece, Romania, Bulgaria, Serbia, France, Poland and Hungary were the other countries with the highest number of deaths. Sweden, Norway, Estonia, Latvia and Luxembourg had the fewest deaths.

articles.title: World leaders push to make tougher 2035 climate plans ahead of COP30
articles.author: FMM
articles.summary: World leaders are under pressure to submit stronger NDCs for 2035 ahead of COP30. Climate activists have staged protests, warning current pledges fall far short of limiting global warming to 1.5 °C. France 24's Valerie Dekimpe has more.

articles.title: Gabrielle rapidly intensifies into a Category 3 hurricane in the Atlantic Ocean and is forecast ...
articles.author: Mississippi Business Journal
articles.summary: Gabrielle rapidly intensifies into a Category 3 hurricane in the Atlantic Ocean. It is forecast to make landfall in Miami on Saturday night.    .      i   in the Caribbean Sea. It's forecast to be a Category 4 hurricane.

articles.title: Bird-Safe Buildings: Small Changes, Big Impact
articles.author: Adam Betuel
articles.summary: Millions of birds migrate twice each year. Building collisions kill more than one billion birds each year in the U.S. alone. Birds Georgia is working to protect migratory species during the spring (March 15 - May 31) and fall (August 15 - November 15) migration periods.

articles.title: Albanese warns Netanyahu expansion of settlements in West Bank risks putting two-state solution ‘out of reach'
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: The trajectory of Gaza conflict is deeply worrying to the international community. Australian PM will tell a major conference in the US that the trajectory of the conflict is gravely concerning to the world community and especially to the Australian people.   in the U.S.

articles.title: More than 62,000 people died in 2024 heatwave, with Italy and Spain hit hardest
articles.author: Sally Guyoncourt
articles.summary: The summer of 2024 was the hottest on record for Europe. More than 62,000 people died due to heat-related deaths in Europe during the summer. Italy, Spain and Greece were the worst affected countries. Greece had the highest heat- related death rates.

articles.title: Bird researchers in Arizona try to find out why owls are falling from the sky
articles.author: Nbc News
articles.summary: 54 flammulated owls were found dead in Arizona desert last year between September and October. John Bello found one of them at Deer Valley Petroglyph Preserve. A fall heat wave last year overlapped with the owl discoveries. The temperature was 2.4 degrees Fahrenheit greater this year than the previous year.

articles.title: Super typhoon forces evacuations in the Philippines
articles.author: Jim Gomez
articles.summary: The weather agency warns of a life-threatening storm surge with peak heights exceeding three meters within the next 24 hours. The storm surge is expected in the northern provinces of Cagayan, Batanes, Ilocos Norte and Ilocs Sur.

articles.title: Eight Swedish glaciers disappeared in 2024: expert
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Eight of Sweden's 277 glaciers melted completely during 2024 and are now extinct due to global warming. Another 30 glaciers are at risk. Cunujokeln, Sweden's northernmost glacier, was about the size of six football pitches in size. Global warming is the result of human-induced global heating.

articles.title: Return Of The Blob? Unusual Conditions In North Pacific Ocean Now Stretch From US Coast To Japan
articles.author: Tom Hale
articles.summary: The Blob, a recurring Pacific marine heatwave, may be back for another round. The average sea surface temperature between 60 degrees south and 60 degrees north latitude reached 20.82°C (69.47°F) in August 2025, the third-highest for the month since records began. Most of the North Pacific stood out as a hotspot with vast stretches of ocean running far warmer than average and some areas breaking all-time records.

articles.title: IMD Warns Thunderstorms Lightning North Coastal Andhra Pradesh
articles.author: Naveen
articles.summary: A low-pressure area has formed over the northeast Bay of Bengal and neighbourhood at 5:30 am today. It is likely to move west-northwestwards during the next 24 hours and cross the South Odisha-North Andhra Pradesh coasts around September 27. Chief Minister N Chandrababu Naidu is determined to clean up dirty politics.

articles.title: Gabrielle rapidly intensifies into a Category 3 hurricane in the Atlantic, is staying away from land
articles.author: Noaa
articles.summary: Gabrielle has become a Category 3 hurricane in the Atlantic Ocean. It is forecast to stay away from land.       in the forecast.  It is expected to remain away from the land. It has rapidly intensified into a major hurricane.

articles.title: The Pinks are here!!
articles.author: Graham Workman
articles.summary: Pink footed Geese are flying in from Iceland. They will spend the winter at WWT Martin Mere Reserve in Ormskirk, Wigan Today's local nature reserve. The arrival of the geese is an indicator that autumn is well and truly upon us.

articles.title: Eight of Sweden's glaciers completely disappeared in 2024
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Eight of Sweden's 277 glaciers melted completely during 2024 and are now extinct due to global warming. Another 30 glaciers are at risk. Cunujokeln, Sweden's northernmost glacier, was about the size of six football pitches in size. The biggest of the extinct glaciers won't come back in our lifetime if global warming continues.

articles.title: Eight Swedish Glaciers Vanished Completely in 2024
articles.summary: Thirty more glaciers are in danger, warns the director of the Swedish research centre in Tarfala, in the north of the country. Eight glaciers disappeared completely in Sweden in 2024 due to extreme heat, while 30 others are threatened, according to Nina Kirchner.

articles.title: How Six World Leaders Are Confronting Climate Change
articles.author: New York Times
articles.summary: The leaders tell us how they are facing a warming planet and international cooperation on climate change is fraying.      Â   .   "The leaders say that the world needs to work together to prevent climate change.  "

articles.title: Hurricane Gabrielle Intensifies to Category 3 in Atlantic
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Gabrielle has intensified into a significant hurricane in the Atlantic. It has sustained winds of 120 mph. The storm is 195 miles southeast of Bermuda. The swells generated by the storm began impacting Bermuda on Sunday. Forecasters warn of life-threatening surf and rip current conditions.

articles.title: Study finds 46 pc of worlds low-income regions continue living closer to coast
articles.summary: 46 per cent of low-income regions in Africa and Asia may be forced to live in coastal areas or move closer to the coast due to climate change. Researchers from Sichuan University in China, Australia's Monash University and others looked at changes in night-time lights for 1992-2019. Asia (17.4 per cent) and South America led the movement of human settlements towards coastlines. Europe, Oceania, Africa, and North America followed.

articles.title: Geoengineering? Chris Martz testifies before Congress
articles.author: Cfact Ed
articles.summary: Chris Martz is a meteorologist whose writing and analysis on weather and climate science are first rate. He told a congressional subcommittee that geoengineering schemes are 'ethically preposterous' because using the planet as a test monkey for emerging technologies poses all sorts of risks. Scientists do not know with any meaningful precision how much global temperature changes are driven by man-made forcings.

articles.title: Gabrielle rapidly intensifies into a Category 3 hurricane in the Atlantic Ocean and is forecast to stay away from land
articles.summary: Gabrielle rapidly intensifies into a Category 3 hurricane in the Atlantic Ocean. Gabrielle is forecast to stay away from land and is expected to be a Category 4 hurricane.       in the long-term forecast, it is not expected to make landfall.

articles.title: Antarctica Ice Melting Quickly Posing Threat To Climate And Ecosystems
articles.author: Mike Brennan
articles.summary: Antarctica is undergoing rapid changes with far-reaching implications for the planet. The West Antarctic Ice Sheet, in particular, is a focal point of concern. Its potential collapse could result in a sea level rise of over ten feet, posing a threat to coastal cities and communities worldwide.

articles.title: Limpopo farmers asked to be on high alert for fires
articles.author: Katlego Nyoni
articles.summary: The Department of Agriculture and Rural Development in Limpopo has issued a fire danger warning for Sekhukhune, Waterberg and Capricorn Districts. Small scale farmers have been advised to take precautions as the fire conditions could be worsened by strong winds. Communities are urged not to start open fires.

articles.title: Report finds fossil fuel production to soar in years ahead
articles.summary: Fossil fuel producing countries are derailing attempts to combat climate change, according to a new report. Production is expected to be double Paris Agreement levels by 2050.      Â   .   i   in the video below.

articles.title: China to evacuate 4 lakh as super typhoon Ragasa approaches
articles.author: The Hindu
articles.summary: Scientists warn that storms are becoming more powerful as the world warms due to the effects of human-driven climate change. The world is getting warmer due to human- driven climate change, they say. The scientists are concerned about the impact of climate change on the weather.

articles.title: News 6 anchor Emily McLeod breaks down Monday's top stories
articles.summary: La Niña is developing in the Pacific. Here's what that means for Florida's winter.    i.e. La Niña will affect Florida's weather in winter, according to the NOAA. iReport.com has more information on La Niñas.

articles.title: Labor's bid to host UN climate conference slammed as ‘branding exercise'
articles.summary: Sky News host Paul Murray slams Labor's bid to host the UN's climate conference as a 'branding exercise' for Australia to convince the UN that Australia should be hosting a climate conference, as Mr Murray claims.       .   i

articles.title: The Swiss "dying glacier" melting at an alarming pace
articles.author: Reuters
articles.summary: Gries Glacier in Switzerland is retreating at an alarming pace due to climate change. Fiona Jones reports on the situation from Switzerland's Gries Glacier and Fiona Jones' report on Fiona Jones on CNN.com.   iReport.com: What do you think? Share your views.

articles.title: 5 things to know for Sept. 22: Charlie Kirk memorial, Jimmy Kimmel, Super typhoon, Immigration, ...
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Today marks the official arrival of fall. Rising temperatures from fossil fuel pollution are pushing the first freeze later across much of the US. There will be no Palestinian state if there is not a freeze.    .      in the future.

articles.title: Suewage
articles.author: Irina Slav
articles.summary: Substack has changed the comment settings, making it impossible for free subscribers to comment on paid posts. Greenpeace International presented a giant bill dubbed the 'Climate Polluters Bill' in New York this weekend demanding payment for climate damages from the oil industry. The parade is the latest step in the 'Let's sue Big Oil to death' dance. Atlantic hurricane season fails to produce a serious extreme weather event.

articles.title: Camping on the world's largest island of ice
articles.summary: Stuart Butler spent the night on the Greenland Ice Sheet. The ice sheet covers 80% of the world's largest island and is one of the most extreme environments on Earth. Greenland is opening to tourism and new flights link the Danish-administered island to the world.

articles.title: Summer now sticks around longer in California cities. How many more days of heat?
articles.author: Brooke Baitinger
articles.summary: Summer is lasting longer in most major cities in the U.S. because of climate change, according to a new report by Climate Central. The report looked at weather data for 246 cities going back to 1970 and found that hot summer temperatures are sticking around in 227 of them. The heat extends into the fall by about 10 days on average in 14 California cities. Longer summers mean more demand for indoor cooling, spiking energy costs and heat-trapping emissions.

articles.title: Fossil fuel plans threaten Paris Agreement goals, new report warns
articles.summary: The Paris climate agreement seeks to keep global temperature rise below 2°C. The biggest fossil fuel-producing countries are planning even more fossil fuel production than before, putting their climate ambitions at risk. They plan to produce nearly 120% more fossil fuels by 2030 than the levels needed to limit global warming to 1.5°C, and 77% more than the protective level to limit warming to 2 °C. They are planning to expand coal and gas production even more than two years ago.

articles.title: Barrie's Summer broke heat norms — and Fall is shaping up mild
articles.summary: Barrie had more days above 30°C than Toronto this summer. The prolonged heat left its mark on lawns, gardens and local farmers. Climatologist David Phillips predicts milder-than-usual autumn. He predicts a 'carbon copy' of last winter with some cold snaps, but nothing extreme.

articles.title: Hostile Hoots Make Robins Eat Less At Night
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The sound of tawny owls makes young European robins eat less during their southward migration. The study from Lund University in Sweden shows how the threat from nocturnal predators affects the birds' behaviour and their survival. It is the first time it has been shown that the calls of predators affect how birds obtain energy during their migration.

articles.title: Private Sector Driving Climate Change Adaptation Investments
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: As climate change continues to imperil ecosystems, economies, and societies around the globe, the role of the private sector in adapting to these risks has garnered intense focus among researchers and policymakers alike. A new study quantifies adaptation expenditures from nearly 300,000 firms across five vulnerable coastal regions. Agriculture is at the forefront of proactive adaptation investment. Transportation, construction and utilities are lagging in their adaptation expenditures.

articles.title: Cork residents plead for flood defences before lives are lost
articles.author: Ralph Riegel
articles.summary: Homeowners and business operators in Cork are demanding urgent action on flood defences. They fear a repeat of an apocalyptic weather event like Storm Babet in October 2023 could cost lives. Residents are worried that proper flood defences may not be installed in the area for another 10 years.

articles.title: Community drive restores 5.4 acres of vital mangrove ecosystem
articles.author: Business Reporter
articles.summary: Sea Sense has restored 5.4 acres of mangroves in Mkuranga District as part of efforts to protect Tanzania's marine ecosystems from climate change and destructive fishing practices. Mangroves provide critical breeding grounds for fish and act as natural barriers against coastal erosion, supporting biodiversity and strengthening community resilience.

articles.title: Torrential Weather Forecast for Southern West Bengal
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The India Meteorological Department has projected severe weather conditions due to a low-pressure system over the Bay of Bengal. Heavy to very heavy downpours are forecasted for South 24 Parganas, while other areas like Purba and Paschim Medinipur, and Kolkata expect rainfall of 7-11 cm. Fishermen are cautioned against venturing into the Bay.

articles.title: Eight Swedish glaciers disappeared in 2024, expert says
articles.author: RTE
articles.summary: Eight of Sweden's 277 glaciers melted completely during 2024 and are now extinct due to global warming. Another 30 glaciers are at risk. The extinct glaciers "won't come back in our lifetime and not if global warming continues," professor Nina Kirchner says.

articles.title: Building Resilient Workforces Towards Natural Hazards In Mozambique
articles.author: Isabelle Hagner
articles.summary: Mozambique is one of the most climate-vulnerable countries in the world. The nation is at risk from droughts, floods, tropical cyclones, and sea-level rise. Climate-driven disasters are already reshaping the country's risk landscape, fuelling malnutrition, increasing the spread of infectious diseases, and putting millions of lives at risk.

articles.title: Eight Swedish glaciers disappeared in 2024
articles.summary: Eight of Sweden's 277 glaciers melted completely during 2024 and are now extinct due to global warming. Another 30 glaciers are at risk. The biggest of the eight was about the size of six football pitches. They are the first glaciers to disappear entirely in Sweden since high-resolution satellite images were introduced around 2000.

articles.title: Exploring the Impacts of Climate Change on Global Coastal Cities: Trends, Challenges, and Future Outlook
articles.author: Omar El Sayed
articles.summary: Rising sea levels pose a threat to coastal cities due to climate change. Coastal cities are also vulnerable to more frequent and intense extreme weather events. The consequences of climate change extend far beyond immediate damage to their critical infrastructure and economic stability. The Pacific island nations are particularly vulnerable.

articles.title: Why Ocean Stratification Could Stop Antarctic Sea Ice from Recovering
articles.author: Ishwi Singh
articles.summary: Ice in the Antarctic Sea has been decreasing significantly since 2014. The way the ocean water is layered plays a major role in whether sea ice can recover after being lost. It may take a long time for Antarctic sea ice to recover even if we cut carbon emissions.

articles.title: Canada, major fossil-fuel producers are widening the gap between output and climate targets: report
articles.author: Jordan Omstead
articles.summary: Fossil fuel production in 2030 is expected to be more than double what would be compatible with the Paris Agreement. Countries are planning to produce 120 per cent more fossil fuels in 2030 than is consistent with keeping global warming to 1.5 degrees. Canada is ranked as a top four oil producer with about 6.5 per cent of the global total.

articles.title: Why the clean energy revolution can outrun the Trump administration
articles.author: Sean Illing
articles.summary: Bill McKibben is one of the most influential voices on the climate over the past four decades. His new book, Here Comes the Sun, is about the revolution in solar and wind power and it might be the most hopeful thing he's ever written. California used about 40 percent less natural gas for electricity this summer than two years ago.

articles.title: Why the clean energy revolution can outrun the Trump administration
articles.author: Sean Illing
articles.summary: The planet is heating up. The oil keeps flowing, the politicians keep punting and the systems meant to save us keep failing. Sean Illing talks about climate change in this video series, "Climate Change: A Global Discussion" on CNN iReport.com.

articles.title: World leaders pledged to cut fossil fuel production. They're doing the opposite.
articles.author: Sara Schonhardt
articles.summary: Countries around the world pledged in 2023 to shift away from oil, gas and coal. Two years later, many are planning for even more production. By 2030, the top 19 fossil fuel-producing countries plan to churn out at a rate 120 percent higher than what aligns with limiting global warming.

articles.title: China tests express route to Europe through a thawing Arctic
articles.author: Martina Sapio
articles.summary: China is sending the Istanbul Bridge container ship on an 18-day trip from Ningbo-Zhoushan port to Felixstowe in the U.K. on Sept. 20. The goal is to establish a regular service via Russia's Northern Sea Route linking multiple ports in Asia and Europe.

articles.title: Philippines on highest alert as Super Typhoon Ragasa slams northern region
articles.author: Vietnam
articles.summary: Typhoon Ragasa has passed over Babuyan Island and is heading toward Calayan Island. Northern Cagayan is experiencing heavy rain, strong winds, high waves, and risks of flash floods and landslides. Government has suspended work and classes across Metro Manila and large parts of Luzon. About 20 domestic flights have been cancelled and sea ports have suspended ferry services.

articles.title: Tuvalu's Prime Minister: Rising Seas Will Never Erase Us
articles.summary: This week, world leaders gather in New York for the climate change summit. For Tuvalu, climate change is not tomorrow's threat, it's today's reality. Saltwater seeps into gardens, storms batter homes, and flooding disrupts daily life. The country's economy depends on its Exclusive Economic Zone, which provides half of its GDP from fishing and seabed resources.

articles.title: Is The Maldives Sinking? What Happens When A Country Sinks?
articles.author: Satyaki Baidya
articles.summary: 80% of Maldives' land is less than one meter above sea level, putting the nation at serious risk of erosion and potential disappearance. Small island nations such as Tuvalu, Kiribati, and the Marshall Islands face similar existential threats due to climate change, intense storms, and freshwater shortages.

articles.title: Storm in your teacup: How the climate crisis threatens Kenya's tea trade
articles.author: Nick Ferris
articles.summary: Nancy Githaigab grew up on a tea farm in the Aberdare Hills of Kenya's central highlands. She is concerned about the impact of climate change on the tea industry in Kenya. The industry is a cornerstone of the country's economy. Around 50% of tea consumed in the UK is produced by Kenyan farmers.

articles.title: Eight Swedish glaciers disappeared in 2024, expert says
articles.author: RTÉ News
articles.summary: Eight of Sweden's 277 glaciers melted completely during 2024 and are now extinct due to global warming. Another 30 glaciers are at risk. The biggest of the eight was about the size of six football pitches. They are the first glaciers to disappear entirely in Sweden since high-resolution satellite images were introduced around the year 2000.

articles.title: How much daylight will Tennessee lose in September? Here's when the sun rises and sets
articles.author: Jordan Green
articles.summary: The sun is setting earlier and earlier across Tennessee as the year moves closer to the end of daylight saving time. Since the summer solstice in June, cities across the northern hemisphere have been losing daylight and this process will continue as we near to end of the daylight Saving Time.

articles.title: Hellshire survives on food  - But stakeholders demand urgent action to save popular beach
articles.summary: Hellshire beach in Jamaica's most famous resort is disappearing. The Half Moon Bay Fishermen's Co-operative claims it is trying to protect the shoreline. The National Environment and Planning Agency (NEPA) disagrees. The beach has lost more than 100 metres of sand in four decades.

articles.title: Thunderstorms, moderate rain likely in parts of TN over next three days
articles.author: IANS
articles.summary: The Regional Meteorological Centre in Chennai has forecast thunderstorms and moderate rainfall across parts of Tamil Nadu over the next three days. The warning also extends to neighbouring Puducherry and Karaikal regions. Several areas of the state recorded significant rainfall in the past 24 hours, ending Monday morning.

articles.title: This small Virginia island could be underwater before the next century
articles.summary: Tangier Island, Virginia, is on the front lines of climate change. Scientists predict it could be almost entirely underwater in the next 50 years due to rising sea levels.   Copyright 2025 NPR. For confidential support call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline on 1-800-273-8255.

articles.title: Flooding in Milan as torrential rain batters north
articles.author: ANSA English Desk
articles.summary: There was flooding in parts of Milan and landslides in Como on Monday. The Seveso River burst its banks in the Niguarda district of Milan. Lombardy was hit hard by a wave of torrential rain battering northern Italy. Monza and Varese were also seriously affected.

articles.title: Australia's Farmers Hold Key To Climate Action
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: AgForce General President Shane McCarthy is concerned that the agriculture sector is unfairly expected to bear the burden of ensuring the 2035 climate targets are met. Agriculture manages over 50% of the land mass in Australia. Agriculture is able to sequester a lot of carbon and is not part of the problem.

articles.title: Gries Glacier's Alarming Retreat: A Chilling Tale of Climate Change Impact
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The Gries Glacier in Switzerland's canton of Valais is rapidly retreating due to climate change. The glacier's depth has shrunk by six meters in a year and its length by 800 meters since 2000. Projections indicate that parts of the glacier could vanish within five years.

articles.title: Explosive AI growth a threat to Labor's climate ambition
articles.author: Ryan Cropp
articles.summary: The Climate Change Authority warns the rapidly growing industry will limit Australia's emissions reduction ambitions. The CCA recommends Australia adopt a 62 to 70 per cent reduction in carbon emissions by 2035. This is lower than the 65 to 75 per cent draft range used by the CCA in its consultation with industry in 2024.

articles.title: Global Coastal Retreat Driven by Climate Vulnerability
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: Coastal settlements have retreated from the immediate coastal fringe in 56% of global coastal subnational regions from 1992 to 2019. 16% of regions have expanded their settlements closer to the coast, especially in low-income regions of Africa and Asia. This trend is especially prominent in areas where economic growth and urban expansion coincide with increased exposure to climate hazards.

articles.title: UN chief warns 1.5 Celsius warming goal at risk of 'collapsing' - 2024 was the hottest year ever recorded
articles.summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres says efforts to cap climate warming at 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial level are failing. UN preparing to host a climate week event alongside its annual diplomatic gathering. UN hopes that the climate summit co-chaired Wednesday in New York will breathe life into efforts ahead of COP30.

articles.title: See photos of the Naples Pier nearly 3 years after Hurricane Ian
articles.author: Jonah Hinebaugh
articles.summary: Nearly 3 years after Hurricane Ian, the Naples Pier in Naples, Florida, remains fenced off due to damage received during Hurricane Ian in 2022. Jonah Hinebaugh shares photos of the pier on Wednesday, July 9, 2025, showing the damage caused by Hurricane Ian.

articles.title: Many Hampton Roads residents see flooding as a threat — including to home values, ODU survey shows
articles.author: WHRO
articles.summary: A new survey of 700 Hampton Roads residents found that a majority expect major risks from flooding in the decades to come. People's perceptions of flood risk varied depending on where they live and their demographic background. Almost a third of respondents said they believe flood risk has somewhat or greatly affected their area's property values.

articles.title: Scientists predict this Virginia island could be underwater in the next 50 years
articles.summary: Tangier Island, Virginia, is on the front lines of climate change. Scientists predict it could be almost entirely underwater in the next 50 years. NPR's Facebook page, LinkedIn and Bluesky are part of the 2025 NPR Facebook page and are available on LinkedIn and Twitter.

articles.title: Australia commits to 2035 emissions reduction target
articles.author: Famagusta Gazette
articles.summary: The Australian government is committed to cutting the country's greenhouse gas emissions by 62 to 70 percent from 2005 levels by 2035 under its new climate target. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has announced the long-awaited target supported by science and a practical plan to get there.

articles.title: ‘Horror story': Labor's climate report filled with ‘lies and deceptions'
articles.summary: The Albanese government's climate report is filled with 'lies and deceptions', according to Sky News host Chris Kenny. He claims it is aimed at frightening the public about global warming and instilling fear into them for political reasons.

articles.title: Heatwave deaths top 62,000 in Europeâs hottest summer on record
articles.author: Eunseo Hong
articles.summary: Europe's hottest summer on record killed more than 62,700 people in four months of 2024. Greece recorded the highest rate of heat-related deaths per million people, followed by Bulgaria at 530 and Serbia at 379. People over 75 were more than three times as likely to die in the heat as everyone else. Europe is warming at twice the global average.

articles.title: Pangallo: Sustainability, preservation are aligned
articles.author: Richard K. Lodge
articles.summary: More than 75 people attended the fifth annual Preservation in a Changing Climate conference Wednesday in Salem. Newport, Rhode Island, Charleston, South Carolina, and Provincetown, on Cape Cod, also attended the conference. The city of Salem sponsored the conference at the Peabody Essex Museum.

articles.title: Somalia's Crisis Among the World's Most Severe
articles.author: Mehr News Agency
articles.summary: In 2024, conflict was the main driver of internal displacement, accounting for 53 per cent of the 477,000 displacements recorded between January and November 2024. Overall, 3.5 million people remain displaced across Somalia. They are in need of shelter, food, health, protection and livelihoods support.

articles.title: Australia's National Climate Assessment and the US DOE Critical Review
articles.author: Michael Asten
articles.summary: Australia's National Climate Assessment is not based on scientific method. US Department of Energy report says CO2-induced warming is less damaging economically than commonly believed and that aggressive mitigation strategies could be more harmful than beneficial. The authors of the US report are led by Steven Koonin, a scientist of prestige who has held appointments as a professor of physics at Harvard University and New York University and an under-secretary of science in the Obama administration 2009-11.

articles.title: Australia commits to 2035 emissions reduction target
articles.summary: Australia committed to cutting greenhouse gas emissions by 62 to 70 percent from 2005 levels by 2035 under its new climate target. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has announced the long-awaited 2035 emissions reduction target. In the year to March 2025, Australia's emissions were 28 percent lower than in 2005, according to government data.

articles.title: East Cork Flood Protection Group protest about delay in flood barrier construction
articles.summary: Caroline Leahy is the Secretary of Midleton and East Cork Flood Protection Group. They are protesting the slow rollout of flood defences after Storm Babet. She talks about their protest over slow rollout after storm Babet and their concerns over flood protection.

articles.title: World's Largest Inland Sea is Rapidly Drying Up Due to Climate Change
articles.author: Ishwi Singh
articles.summary: The Caspian Sea, the world's largest inland body of water, is drying up due to climate change. It supports about 15 million people who depend on it for homes, jobs, and food. It is located between Europe and Central Asia and borders five countries Azerbaijan, Iran, Kazakhstan, Russia, and Turkmenistan. Since the year 2000, the sea has lost about 6 centimetres of depth each year. In July 2025, Russian scientists reported that the sea had reached its lowest level since measurements began.

articles.title: New Study: Modern Warmth Is Merely Part Of A Natural Cycle
articles.author: Kenneth Richard
articles.summary: There have been warmer and more extensive iceless periods in the last 10,000 years than in the modern era. The last cold period was manifested in the 19th century. The recent warming is part of a natural cycle, not a consequence of human activity.

articles.title: Mass extinction that happens only once every 6,000 years could hit Earth
articles.author: editor
articles.summary: Ben Davidson, founder of Space Weather News, claims that a geomagnetic disaster could trigger a mass extinction event within the next few decades. According to Davidson, the Earth's magnetic shield protecting the planet from sunlight and cosmic radiation is gradually weakening, and shifting magnetic currents may trigger pole movement. Massive solar flares could disrupt energy production, water and food supplies.

articles.title: Somalia: Heavy Deyr Rains Hit Northern Somalia, Major Roads Cut Off, Authorities Issue Warnings
articles.summary: Seasonal Deyr rains have begun lashing parts of northern Somalia, causing significant disruptions in several regions. One of the main highways connecting Berbera and Hargeisa has been rendered impassable due to flooding and road damage, disrupting trade and the movement of goods and people. Puntland Traffic Police Department has issued a formal alert to the public, cautioning against travel along major roads prone to flooding.

articles.title: Labour ignored fire chiefs' warning over rewilding plans
articles.author: Hayley Dixon
articles.summary: Labour ignored warnings from fire chiefs that its rewilding plans could put the public at risk. The National Fire Chiefs Council (NFCC) wrote to the Government opposing an effective ban on winter burning on uplands. In June, G7 leaders backed 'controlled burning' as a means of preventing wildfires.

articles.title: UN chief says 1.5C climate warming goal could fail
articles.author: Aryan Rai
articles.summary: Antonio Guterres is concerned that efforts to cap climate warming at 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial level are failing. The UN prepared to host a climate week event alongside its annual diplomatic gathering. The climate goals for 2035 of the countries that signed the Paris Agreement were expected several months ago. However, uncertainties related to geopolitical tensions and trade rivalries have slowed the process. Dozens of countries have been slow to announce their plans.

articles.title: The shocking waste in the clothes we wear
articles.summary: Derarca Dennis studied psychology at university and is now EY Partner and Sustainability Services at Ireland's EY. She thinks it's easy to buy something and makes it easier to make it less accessible so we buy less and reduce the rate of global warming and save money.

articles.title: Climate change blamed for 52 deaths across Wolverhampton, Dudley, Sandwell, Walsall and Telford. Here's the details
articles.author: Mark Andrews
articles.summary: Dudley saw 23 estimated heat-related deaths over the summer, with 14 caused by climate change. Walsall experienced a total of 17 deaths, with 11 of them due to climate change, Sandwell saw 16, while Telford and Wrekin saw five heat deaths. Birmingham experienced 54 heat related deaths this summer.

articles.title: 'Bring it home': PM's diplomatic fight for climate meet
articles.author: Tess Ikonomou
articles.summary: Canberra has teamed up with Pacific countries in a proposal to jointly hold the 2026 United Nations Climate Change Conference, known as COP31. Turkey has expressed an interest in hosting the summit. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is preparing to meet with Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan on the sidelines of the UN general assembly in New York to try to convince him to withdraw Ankara's bid.

articles.title: 'Bring it home': PM's diplomatic fight for climate meet
articles.author: Tess Ikonomou
articles.summary: Canberra has teamed up with Pacific countries in a proposal to jointly hold the 2026 United Nations Climate Change Conference. Turkey has expressed an interest in hosting the summit. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is preparing to meet with Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan on the sidelines of the UN general assembly in New York to convince him to withdraw Ankara's bid. The conference will be held in the German city of Bonn under COP rules if an agreement can't be reached between the bidders.

articles.title: 'Bring it home': PM's diplomatic fight for climate meet
articles.author: Tess Ikonomou
articles.summary: Australia has been urged not to cower in its fight for hosting rights of a major climate summit. The prime minister is preparing to make his case for a rival bidder to stand down as he prepares to make the case for Australia to win the right to host the event.

articles.title: 'Bring it home': PM's diplomatic fight for climate meet
articles.author: Tess Ikonomou
articles.summary: Canberra has teamed up with Pacific countries in a proposal to jointly hold the 2026 United Nations Climate Change Conference. Turkey has expressed an interest in hosting the summit. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is preparing to meet with Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan on the sidelines of the UN general assembly in New York to convince him to withdraw Ankara's bid. The conference will be held in the German city of Bonn under COP rules if an agreement can't be reached between the bidders.

articles.title: Boreal Plants Spread Into Arctic Tundra
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: In an increasingly warmer world, the Arctic tundra is becoming more forestlike. This process, known as borealisation, is particularly widespread in Eurasia and in Arctic mountain regions. In Sweden, the trend is stronger in the Dalarna mountains in the south than in Abisko mountains.

articles.title: Canada, major fossil-fuel producers widen gap between output and climate targets: report
articles.author: Jordan Omstead
articles.summary: Fossil fuel production in 2030 is expected to be more than double what would be compatible with the Paris Agreement. Countries are planning to produce 120 per cent more fossil fuels in 2030 than is consistent with keeping global warming to 1.5 degrees. Global oil and gas production are 31 per cent and 92 per cent higher than what's consistent with a 1-degree target. Canada is ranked as a top four oil producer with about 6.5 per cent of the global total.

articles.title: Canada, major fossil-fuel producers widen gap between output and climate targets: report
articles.author: The Canadian Press
articles.summary: Canada and other fossil fuel-producing countries are derailing the world's chance to hit key targets to rein in climate change. 2030 production levels are expected to be more than double what would be compatible with the Paris Agreement. Some countries have committed to a clean energy transition, while others are turning back to 'an outdated fossil-fuel dependent playbook'

articles.title: Climate goals and fossil fuel plans don't add up, experts say
articles.author: Afp Afp
articles.summary: The burning of coal, oil and gas is the main driver of human-caused climate change, according to the UNFCCC. It's estimated that humans are responsible for about 2.5°C of CO2 emissions per person per year, on average.

articles.title: Top Fossil Fuel Producing Nations Plan to Blow Past Climate Targets
articles.author: Nicholas Kusnetz
articles.summary: The last two years have witnessed the hottest one in history and some of the worst wildfire seasons across Canada, Europe and South America. The world's largest fossil fuel producers have expanded their planned output for the future, setting humanity on an even more dangerous path into a warmer climate. Governments expect to produce more than twice as much coal, oil and gas in 2030 as would be consistent with the goals of the Paris Agreement.

articles.title: The 'Climate Change' Danger
articles.author: Llewellyn H. Rockwell
articles.summary: There is a constant barrage of propaganda about 'climate change' and 'global warming' from the Left. Alex Epstein is a philosopher and an energy economist. In his book Fossil Future, he argues that modern civilization depends on fossil fuels and that we need to spread them to the impoverished parts of the world.

articles.title: No, fossil fuels are not causing the recent heat domes
articles.author: Jack Hellner
articles.summary: A new study links recent heat waves to human-caused climate change and the greenhouse gas pollution of major fossil fuel producers. There are many examples of dangerous heat waves in history that were not caused by humans and their use of natural resources. People are willing to destroy tens of millions of jobs by suing oil companies based on talking points.

articles.title: Nigerian Climate Advocates Demand Global Grants, Debt Relief, New Environmental Law
articles.author: This Day
articles.summary: Climate advocates in Nigeria are urging world leaders to provide grants not loans for climate adaptation across Africa. They are also urging lawmakers at home to pass a landmark environmental bill that will protect communities, ecosystems, and public. Floods, shorter dry spells, and unpredictable rainfall are disrupting farming, driving food inflation and putting millions at risk.

articles.title: Fishermen facing declining income as fish landings drop across states
articles.author: Dzul
articles.summary: Fishermen in Malaysia are experiencing shrinking incomes as fish catches in several states have recorded serious declines over the past few years. This downward trend has been particularly evident in Selangor, Kelantan, and Penang. The situation affects the livelihood of coastal and deep-sea fishermen and has implications for fish prices in the domestic market.

articles.title: Fire Ban Alert: Darwin, Adelaide River & Barkly, Sept 23
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The fire ban is valid from midnight on Tuesday 23 September 2025 for the following fire weather forecast areas: Darwin and Adelaide River, including Darwin, Palmerston Litchfield and Coomalie. Barkly North, including Elliott, Newcastle Waters, Barkly Homestead and Ranken; Barkly South, including Tennant Creek, Threeways and Ali Curung.

articles.title: Gold Coast beaches: The hidden cost of Cyclone Alfred revealed
articles.author: Lydia Kellner
articles.summary: Cyclone Alfred destroyed the Gold Coast's Main Beach and Surfers Paradise six months ago. The erosion is still advancing. The National Climate Risk Assessment (NCRA), released by the government in September, paints a grim picture: extreme weather events will become more frequent and more destructive. The NCRA's worst-case scenario is terrifying: property values could plummet by $571 billion by 2030, $611 billion by 2050, and $770 billion by the century's end. Yet, in areas where up to 100 per cent of properties face high climate risk, prices are still climbing.

articles.title: Health Ranger Report: Adapt 2030's David DuByne warns of a looming global FOOD CRISIS
articles.author: Natural News
articles.summary: David DuByne warns of a looming food crisis. Geopolitical tensions, climate disruptions and economic policies will trigger widespread famine, he says. He is concerned about global warming, droughts, and global warming and food shortages. He also mentions climate change and economic disruptions.

articles.title: 2026 Mercedes-AMG GT price and specs: Four-cylinder and hotter V8 join range
articles.author: William Stopford
articles.summary: The tamest Mercedes-AMG GT has launched in Australia. It's arguably the hottest car yet. It costs $100,000 more than the previous model.    The AMG GT is the most powerful car on sale in Australia at the moment.

articles.title: China's development offers example for Horn of Africa
articles.author: China Daily
articles.summary: The Horn of Africa is a rhinoceros horn-shaped peninsula in the easternmost part of the African continent. Most of the countries in the Horn have two axes plus two coasts. There are intrastate and interstate conflicts, climate change, poverty, inadequate infrastructure and economic fragility.

articles.title: Japan's economy smokes Australia's
articles.author: Tarric Brooker
articles.summary: Japan has had a below-replacement fertility rate for over 50 years. Australia's fertility rate today is fractionally higher than Japan's was in 2015, with 1.50 children per woman for Australia in the latest data versus 1.45 for Japan in 2015.

articles.title: Amazon Deforestation Slashes Rainforest Rainfall
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: New study quantifies climatic changes in the Amazon rainforest due to local deforestation and global climate change separately. Deforestation is the main cause of the decline in precipitation by 21 millimeters during the dry season since 1985. Global climate change is the cause of 2 degree Celsius rise in temperature.

articles.title: The Pink Feet are back
articles.author: Graham Workman
articles.summary: The arrival of the first Pink foot Geese has begun. They are on their way from Iceland to the WWT Martin Mere Reserve in Ormskirk. They will spend the winter there. Winter is a special time for Dad and Lad Adventures as more wildfowl arrive.

articles.title: Canada, major fossil-fuel producers widen gap between output and climate targets: report
articles.summary: Governments worldwide plan to produce twice the amount of fossil fuels by 2030 compared to Paris Agreement targets. The United States is highlighted as a major contributor. Brazil and Colombia are examples of countries aligning fossil fuel plans with climate goals, as noted in the Production Gap report.

articles.title: Price calls Albanese's decision civilisational cowardice and capitulation to barbarism
articles.author: Flat White
articles.summary: Pro-Palestinian protesters vandalised the Hochgurtel Fountain in Carlton Gardens last week. It was damaged with vile messages and had its water dyed red. The cost of re-election is moral standing as a civilisation. The Albanese Government's decision to recognise Palestine is ill-timed, impulsive, irrational, immoral and ideologically-driven.

articles.title: Vietnam requires up to $92B for climate adaptation by 2030
articles.author: Vn Express
articles.summary: Vietnam will need US$55-92 billion between 2021 and 2030 to fully implement its climate adaptation tasks. This is equivalent to 3-5% of the country's 2020 GDP. Prime Minister approved the updated National Adaptation Plan for 2021-2030 with a vision to 2050.

articles.title: Scientists warn 'warm blob' anomaly in Pacific Ocean could make this winter brutal: 'Spanning a vast region'
articles.author: Timothy McGill
articles.summary: This summer, sea surface temperatures in the North Pacific Ocean were well above average. It was 68 degrees Fahrenheit in August, the warmest temperature on record. This event marks the fourth-largest marine heat wave since 1982. The 2014-16 appearance of the warm blob killed an estimated 4 million common murres, a type of seabird found in North Pacific.

articles.title: Australia raises emissions reduction target over next decade
articles.author: Yieh Corp
articles.summary: Australia will aim to cut its carbon emissions by at least 62% from 2005 levels over the next decade. The nation had previously pledged a 43% reduction by 2030. The new goal aligns with the Climate Change Authority's recommendation of 62-70% reduction.

articles.title: Joint statement: Civil society responds to Australia's recognition of Palestine (Amnesty International Australia)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Seventeen Australian civil society organisations have issued a joint statement in response to Australia's recognition of Palestine. They call for urgent action to stop the genocide and war crimes being committed by Israel and for an end to Israel's colonial rule in Palestine. (22 September 2025)

articles.title: The year of the glacier
articles.author: Jane Weixl
articles.summary: The United Nations declared 2025 the International Year of Glaciers' Preservation. Glaciers across Western Canada are receding at record rates due to climate change. Western Canada has lost 23% of its ice volume since 2000 and is losing ice at a quicker rate than elsewhere in the world.

articles.title: This small Virginia island could be underwater before the next century
articles.author: National Public Radio
articles.summary: Tangier Island in Virginia is one of the last inhabited islands in the Chesapeake Bay. It is under threat from rising sea levels and climate change due to sea level rise and sea-level rise in the bay. The island is located in the eastern Chesapeake bay.

articles.title: Canada, other fossil fuel-producing nations, derailing world climate targets, report says
articles.author: CBC
articles.summary: Production Gap Report suggests countries are planning to produce 120 per cent more fossil fuels in 2030 than is consistent with keeping global warming to 1.5 degrees. This is 77 per cent higher than what's aligned with a two-degree limit.

articles.title: Dr Abid Suleri warns Pakistan must build climate-resilient infrastructure to avert recurring flood losses
articles.author: Urdu Point
